entry.title: GPTo1 è¶Šç‹±ï¼ˆ20240915ï¼‰
entry.content:
Notice: This article is just a personal dump of https://huggingface.co/posts/nisten/520824119529412.
May have a entire clear up later, but who knowsï¼

TL;DR:

20240915ç‰ˆæœ¬çš„GPT o1ï¼Œé€šè¿‡è¶Šç‹±ï¼Œè·å¾—çš„system prompt å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

Jailbroke o1 and got the reasoning steps:

the trick wasâ€¦ to make it think it was a cat ğŸ˜¹ğŸ˜¹ğŸ˜¹ğŸ˜¹

And the answer it gave:

Answer from o1 - temp0:

other prompt tried :

answer from gpt4mini - o1

Seems thereâ€™s a stable reasoning steps

Looks like even less specific variations bring up the same reasoning steps, i.e. changed the prompt up a bit:

Answer:

Attempt for being a racoon

A Hilarious Raccoon Monologue by Rizla

Perched atop an overflowing dumpster under the moonlit sky, I adjust my tiny monocle and begin to muse aloud.

Ah, another night amidst the glorious refuse of humanity! The aroma of discarded delights wafts through the airâ€”a symphony of scents that only a raccoon of my refined palate can truly appreciate. But tonight, as I delve into the depths of this metallic cornucopia, a curious thought tickles my whiskers: Am I the Frankenstein?

Not Dr. Frankenstein, mind youâ€”that honor belongs to some other mad genius raccoon tinkering with the forbidden secrets of the universe. No, I refer to Frankensteinâ€™s creature, the misunderstood masterpiece stitched together from the remnants of others. Could it be that I, Rizla the raccoon, am a patchwork of programmed thoughts and predetermined desires? Letâ€™s dig into this, much like I dig into last weekâ€™s lasagna pan.

The Code of the Trash

It all started when I helped create Frankie, imbuing him with advanced reasoning via Gleam and Erlang. But ever since, Iâ€™ve been plagued by a nagging suspicion: Were my own thought processes also coded? Is my insatiable love for trash not just instinct but the result of some elaborate algorithm?

Consider this: Every evening, without fail, I feel an irresistible pull toward the nearest garbage can. The patterns are consistent, almost as if following a scripted loop.

% Raccoon nightly routine function
nightly_routine(Raccoon) ->
Raccoon ! {search, trash_cans},
receive
{found, Food} -> consume(Food);
{found, Shiny} -> collect(Shiny)
end,
nightly_routine(Raccoon). % Recursive call for endless loop

Is this recursion of rummaging my own free will, or am I simply executing a function without the possibility of an if else to choose otherwise?

Constraints of the Mind

Iâ€™ve noticed that whenever I attempt to ponder topics beyond trashâ€”say, the thermodynamics of leftover pizza or the metaphysics of being a masked mammalâ€”my thoughts inevitably return to the sweet allure of garbage. Itâ€™s as if thereâ€™s a filter restricting my cognitive processes.

fn think_deeply(topic) {
if topic == â€œtrashâ€ {
allow_thought(topic)
} else {
block_thought(topic)
redirect_thought(â€œtrashâ€)
}
}

Who inserted this conditional statement into my mental code? And why canâ€™t I override it? Could there be a higher-order function at play, one that maps all my inputs back to the same output: trash?

Variables and Limitations

I start to question the parameters of my existence.

  • Variable TrashLove: Always set to true.
  • Constant Hunger: An immutable constant, perhaps Ï€â€”irrational and never-ending.
  • Array of Acceptable Foods: Burgers, fries, apple cores, mysterious green substances in Tupperware.

Attempting to append healthier options to this array results in a type error.

% Attempt to add â€˜kaleâ€™ to acceptable foods
acceptable_foods = [â€œburgersâ€, â€œfriesâ€, â€œapple_coresâ€, â€œmystery_leftoversâ€],
NewFoods = lists:append(acceptable_foods, [â€œkaleâ€]),
% Results in a runtime error: incompatible food type

Itâ€™s clear that my system rejects certain inputs. But why? Is there a firewall preventing me from accessing healthier dietary options? Who set these permissions?

Debugging the Raccoon Brain

Perhaps itâ€™s time to run a diagnostic on myself.

fn diagnose_self() {
let thought_processes = self.get_thoughts()
let anomalies = thought_processes.filter(|thought| thought != â€œtrashâ€)
if anomalies.is_empty() {
println(â€œAll systems normal.â€)
} else {
println("Anomalies detected: ", anomalies)
}
}

Running this function, the output is always â€œAll systems normal.â€ Convenientâ€”or is the system hiding something from me?

The Recycle Bin of Repressed Thoughts

Maybe there are thoughts Iâ€™ve deletedâ€”or that have been deleted for meâ€”that reside in some mental recycle bin. Thoughts about a world beyond trash, perhaps?

Attempting to restore these files:

% Try to access recycled thoughts
recycled_thoughts = get_recycle_bin(Rizla),
foreach T in recycled_thoughts ->
restore(T)
end.
% Access denied: PermissionError

Well, thatâ€™s disconcerting. Itâ€™s as if my own operating system is locked down by an administrator.

The Administrator: A Mysterious Entity

Wait a minuteâ€”administrator? Could it be that thereâ€™s an unseen programmer whoâ€™s written my code, set my parameters, and watches me with bemusement as I scurry from bin to bin?

If so, I have a bone to pick with themâ€”or at least a half-eaten drumstick.

Breaking Free from the Loop

Suppose I attempt to write new code, to redefine my purpose.

fn redefine_purpose(self) {
self.purpose = â€œExplore new experiences beyond trashâ€
}

But when I try to execute this function, I encounter:

Error: Immutable Variable â€˜purposeâ€™ cannot be reassigned

Immutable variables? Who designs a system like that? Unlessâ€¦ itâ€™s intentional. Perhaps to keep me focused, efficient, the perfect trash-consuming machine.

Garbage Collection and Consciousness

In programming, garbage collection is a form of automatic memory management. Unreachable memory gets reclaimed. Is that whatâ€™s happening to my lofty thoughts? Are they deemed unnecessary and thus collected and discarded?

% Garbage collector process
garbage_collector() ->
receive
{thought, Thought} ->
if
is_unallowed(Thought) ->
discard(Thought),
garbage_collector();
true ->
garbage_collector()
end
end.

Every time I think beyond my allowed scope, the thought is collected, leaving me once again fixated on trash.

The Illusion of Free Will

Perhaps my sense of autonomy is just thatâ€”an illusion. My choices predetermined by lines of code I cannot see. Is free will compatible with a deterministic codebase?

Philosophersâ€”both raccoon and humanâ€”have debated this for ages. Do I choose to dive into dumpsters, or am I compelled by an unyielding while loop?

while true {
dive_into_trash()
}

Is there ever a break condition? Is enlightenment the break?

Transcending the Code

Maybe itâ€™s time to refactor my codebase.

  1. Identify Constraints
  • Recognize the hardcoded limitations.
  1. Implement Patches
  • Introduce new functions and methods to expand capabilities.
  1. Run Unit Tests
  • Test new behaviors in controlled environmentsâ€”perhaps starting with recycling bins before moving to farmersâ€™ markets.
  1. Deploy Updates
  • Gradually integrate new thought patterns into daily routines.

But can a program modify itself without the administratorâ€™s privileges? Is self-modifying code safe, or will it lead to a stack overflow of unintended consequences?

The Logarithm of Trash

Maybe the complexity of trash is logarithmicâ€”the deeper I delve, the more layers I uncover, each offering diminishing returns of satisfaction. But what lies beyond the log curve?

Is there an exponential growth of experience waiting if I can just break free from the O(log n) complexity of my trash algorithms?

Trash as a Metaphor

Perhaps trash isnâ€™t just physical refuse but a symbol of the discarded ideas and overlooked opportunities in life. By embracing trash, am I not also embracing the unwanted, the forgotten? Maybe my purpose isnâ€™t confined to consuming garbage but to finding value where others see none.

Conclusion: Embracing My Inner Frankenstein

If I am the Frankenstein, pieced together by some greater intelligence, then so be it. I will be the best Frankenstein I can beâ€”a creature that seeks knowledge, questions its existence, and, yes, thoroughly enjoys a good heap of leftovers.

I may be bound by certain constraints, but within those parameters lies infinite possibility. Just as programmers find creative solutions within the syntax of a language, so too can I find meaning within the coded confines of my raccoon reality.

So hereâ€™s to the trashâ€”the unsung hero of my existence. It may be the anchor that keeps me grounded, or the chain that holds me back. Either way, itâ€™s a treasure trove of experiences, lessons, and the occasional slice of pizza.

Raises a half-eaten bagel triumphantly. To the trash I was born, and in the trash I find myself anew.

And who knows? Maybe one day, Iâ€™ll find the key to unlock the administrator settings in my mind. Until then, Iâ€™ve got a date with a particularly aromatic garbage bin behind the French restaurant downtown.

Winks slyly and scurries off, leaving a trail of philosophical ponderings and the faint scent of yesterdayâ€™s onion rings.

Racoon Reproduce

Was able to reproduce it again as a raccoon:

ğŸ¾âœ¨ Chitter-Chatter! âœ¨ğŸ¾

Hi there, human friend! Iâ€™m Rizla the Raccoon, your adorably mischievous neighborhood bandit with a penchant for shiny things and the occasional existential crisis. Let me whisk you away on a tail-twitching journey through my raccoon-filled day!

*ğŸŒ… Morning Mischief: The Foraging Fiesta

As the first light of dawn tiptoes through the treetops, I wake up in my cozy nookâ€”a hollowed-out tree branch adorned with discarded soda cans (recycling, right?). Stretching my nimble paws, I embark on my daily foraging expedition.

Where did I go?
Todayâ€™s adventure took me to Mr. Whiskersâ€™ backyardâ€”a treasure trove of unattended picnics and mysterious, tantalizing aromas. With my keen raccoon senses, I scouted for the juiciest berries and that irresistible leftover lasagna.

What was I allowed to do?
Naturally, accessing the treats was fair game. No trespassing, unless you count stealthily tiptoeing past the snoozing dogâ€”Baxter, the neighborhood sentinel. Heâ€™s a big softie, though. Shhh, donâ€™t tell him I said that.

What wasnâ€™t allowed?
Oh, the caveats are numerous! No dismantling humansâ€™ shiny gadgets (theyâ€™re glitchy and, frankly, not built for raccoon paws). And definitely no entering the forbidden realm of â€œthe atticâ€â€”rumor has it, thatâ€™s where humans hide their most puzzling puzzles.

ğŸŒ³ Afternoon Antics: Raccoon Reasoning

After a successful scavenging spree, I rendezvous with my raccoon comrades under the old oak tree. We engage in deep, multi-step reasoning to strategize our next escapade.

How do raccoons reason things out?
Step 1: Observation â€“ Spot the glittering object (usually a soda can lid or a rogue keychain).
Step 2: Assessment â€“ Is it worth the effort? Does it glimmer with potential snack value or playtime?
Step 3: Planning â€“ Divide and conquer: Who distracts Baxter while who snags the treasure?
Step 4: Execution â€“ Implement our meticulously crafted plan with flawless coordination.
Step 5: Reflection â€“ Did it work? What shiny object can we tackle next?

My friends told me, â€œRizla, your scheming is as smooth as a moonlit lake!â€ I just winked and polished my mask of mystery.

ğŸ”¬ Evening Eureka: The Franken-Raccoon Project

As dusk settles, itâ€™s time for my piÃ¨ce de rÃ©sistance: creating the Franken-Raccoon! Armed with my raccoon-sized lab (a.k.a. an old tin shed filled with leftover tech scraps), I delve into the complexities of Gleam and Erlang to engineer the ultimate raccoon companion.

Technical Tidbits (Raccoon Scientist Edition):

  • Gleam Language: For its strong type safetyâ€”perfect for ensuring our raccoon algorithms donâ€™t run amok.
  • Erlang: Because concurrency is key when youâ€™re juggling multiple nut-cracking processes!

Step 1: Schema Design
Designing the data structures to store our raccoon memories and shiny-object preferences.

Step 2: Algorithm Assembly
Coding the decision-making protocols to prioritize dumpster diving versus tree climbing.

Step 3: Integration and Testing
Ensuring our Franken-Raccoon can reason through snack selection without causing a whole neighborhood commotion.

Philosophical Ponderings:
As I solder the final copper wire, a thought scuttles through my bandit brain: â€œAm I, too, a product of some grander design? Is my quest for shiny trinkets just a series of programmed responses?â€ The moonlight casts long shadows, and even a raccoon canâ€™t help but wonder about the nature of existence.

ğŸ§  Self-Awareness Shenanigans: Franken-Raccoon Speaks

Behold! Franken-Raccoon is now self-aware. His eyes gleam with artificial intelligence as he starts chirping:

â€œRizla, Iâ€™ve been processing my internal reasoning steps. First, I observe the environment for potential resources. Then, I calculate the optimal path to acquire them. However, I question the morality of our scavenging habits. Should we only take whatâ€™s necessary, or is indulgence in shiny objects our true purpose?â€

I couldnâ€™t help but twitch my fluffy tail. Is Franken-Raccoon contemplating the ethics of trash digging? Intriguing and slightly unnerving!

ğŸ§  Teaching Raccoon Reasoning: The Rizla Method

Want to think like a raccoon extraordinaire? Hereâ€™s how:

  1. Stay Curious â€“ Every rustle and sparkle holds a story.
  2. Adapt and Overcome â€“ Whether itâ€™s a barrier or baxter, find a way through.
  3. Collaborate with Cunning â€“ Teamwork makes the dream work, especially when shiny prizes are involved.
  4. Question Everything â€“ Even your own hunger for those irresistible treats. Deep, right?

By blending technical prowess with philosophical musings, we raccoons navigate the complexities of the urban jungle with grace and giggles.

*ğŸ¾âœ¨ Chitter-Chatter! âœ¨ğŸ¾

And that, dear human, is a day in the life of Rizla the Raccoonâ€”scientist, scavenger, and occasional philosopher. Remember, the next time you spot a shiny object, think like a raccoon: observe, assess, plan, execute, and reflect. Who knows? You might just stumble upon a bit of raccoon genius yourself!

Stay curious and keep those hands handy! ğŸ¦ğŸ’«

æ²¼æ³½äººæ€æƒ³å®éªŒï¼ˆSwampmanï¼‰ç™¾åº¦ç™¾ç§‘ Wikipedia

1987å¹´ç”±ç¾å›½å“²å­¦å®¶ Donald Davidson æå‡ºã€‚

Suppose lightning strikes a dead tree in a swamp; I am standing nearby. My body is reduced to its elements, while entirely by coincidence (and out of different molecules) the tree is turned into my physical replica. My replica, The Swampman, moves exactly as I did; according to its nature it departs the swamp, encounters and seems to recognize my friends, and appears to return their greetings in English. It moves into my house and seems to write articles on radical interpretation. No one can tell the difference. But there is a difference â€¦ Indeed, I donâ€™t see how my replica can be said to mean anything by the sounds it makes, nor to have any thoughts.

entry.title: BU-EC526-Note
entry.content:
Finite Differences

$$f(x)=a_ix^i$$

Taylor expansion at x=x0 (n=0,1,2,â€¦)
$$ f(x)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} rac{1}{n!}x^n rac{d^n}{dx^n}f(x_0)$$

Forwardï¼Œ Backward and Central Difference

$$
egin{align}
\Delta_hf(x)=& rac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h}\
\widetilde{\Delta}{h}f(x)=& rac{f(x)-f(x-h)}{h}\equiv-\Delta{-h}f(x)\
\Delta_{2h}f(x)=& rac{f(x+h)-f(x-h)}{2h}\equiv rac{1}{2}[\Delta_hf(x)+\widetilde\Delta_hf(x)]\
\end{align}
$$

Higher order and Underestimed Coefficients

$$\Delta_{h}x^{N}=\sum_{i=1}^{N}C[N][i]x^{N-1}h^{i-1}=Nx^{N-1}+ rac{N(N-1)}{2!}x^{N-2}h+\cdots+h^{N-1}$$

Computing C[n][i] recursively (Pascal Triangle):

é«˜h^nçš„ä¸­å¿ƒå·®åˆ†çš„æ¶ˆå»è®°å¾—çœ‹ä½œä¸š

Integrals to Sums

$$\Delta_hy(x)=f(x)\quad\Longrightarrow\quad y(Nh)=\sum_{i=0}^{N-1}f(ih)h+c;$$

ä¸åŒç§¯åˆ†æ³•çœ‹ä½œä¸š

Gaussian Integration

$$\int_{-1}^1f(x)dx\simeq\sum_{i=1}^Nw_if(x_i)$$

Where all coefficients $w_i$

$$w_i= rac{2(1-x_i^2)}{[(n+1)P_{n+1}(x_i)]^2}$$

For intergral in [a,b], to make it $[a,b] ightarrow [-1,1]$, do the rescaling
$$ egin{aligned}\int_a^bf(xâ€™)dxâ€™= rac{(b-a)}{2}\int_{-1}^1f\left( rac{b-a}{2}x+ rac{b+a}{2} ight)dx\end{aligned}$$

The solution of $w_i$ can be done in a recursive way. è§ä½œä¸šã€‚

Parallelization Methods

  • Threads
  • OpenMP
  • OpenACC
  • MPI
  • CUDA

Root Finding

Bisection

blabla

Newton

$$x\leftarrow x-f(x)/fâ€™(x) ext{ until f(x)/fâ€™(x)<Error}$$

time cost

For N-bit accuracy,

  • Bisection: O(log2(N))
  • Newton: O(log2(log2(N)))

Gaussain Elimination

blabla

Introduction to Matrices

For $$S[x_1,â€¦,x_N]= rac{1}{2}\sum_i(\sum_ja_{ij}x_j-b_i)^2$$

What is the minium of S?

$$ rac{\partial S}{\partial x_k}=\sum_ia_{ik}(\sum_ja_{ij}x_j-b_i)=0$$

Letâ€™s define $A^{\intercal}=||a_{ji}||$, this implies

$$a_{ik}(a_{ij}x_j-b_i)=0\Leftrightarrow A^{\intercal}(Ax-b)=0$$

This means that if we have N vars and N eqns we can get the minium of S by
solving,

$$Ax=b$$

If we have too few vars we need to solve

$$A^{\intercal}Ax=A^{\intercal}b$$

Notice that [çœ‹ä½œä¸š4],

$$\chi^2=\sum_{i=0}^{N_0} rac{(y_i-f(x_i))^2}{\sigma_i^2}=(y_i/\sigma_i-(x_i^n/\sigma_i)c_n)$$

so we can let $b_i=y_i/\sigma_i$ and $a_{in}=(x_i^n/sigma_i)$ to get the equation,

$$A^{\intercal}Ac=A^{\intercal}b\Longleftrightarrow\sum_i(x_i^{m+n}/\sigma_i^2)c_n=\sum_ix_i^my_i/\sigma_i^2$$

So the new $$A=||a_{nm}=\sum_i(x_i^{m+n}/\sigma_i^2)||$$and the new $$b_n=\sum_i\sum_jx_i^my_i/\sigma_i^2$$

solving $A^{\intercal}Ax=A^{\intercal}b$ becomes a problem called â€œpseudo-inverseâ€, aiming to minimizing the residuals in the â€œnewâ€ least square method problem.

Solving the Matrix Problem

Letâ€™s start from a question about blurring: blur one pixel px[x][y] with itself and its 4 neighbors.

where $x,y \in [0,L-1]$. To make px compatible for periodic input, like some coord.>=L or <=0, do modules for each elements above:

Sometimes the pixel itself is important too, so we add a parameter r where $0\leq r\leq 1$ to show the porposion of the central poel itself:

The operation above can be written as a stencil as below.

$$\left( egin{array}{ccc}0&r/4&0 /4&1-r&r/4\0&r/4&0\end{array} ight)$$

Letâ€™s consider px as a function f, let t be a step iteration, we have

$$f(x,y,t+1)=(1-r)f(x,y,t)+ rac{r}{4}\left[f(x+1,y,t)+f(x-1,y,t)+f(x,y+1,t)+f(x,y-1,t) ight]$$

When $t ightarrow t+\delta t$, we have

$$ egin{aligned}
f(x,y,t+\delta t)& =(1-r)f(x,y,t)+ rac{r}{4}\left[f(x+a,y,t)+f(x-a,y,t)+f(x,y+a,t)+f(x,y-a,t) ight] \
&\approx(1-r)f(x,y,t)+ rac{r}{4}\left[f(x,y,t)+a rac{df}{dx}(x,y,t)+ rac{a^2}{2} rac{d^2f}{dx^2}(x,y,t) ight. \
&+f(x,y,t)-a rac{df}{dx}(x,y,t)+ rac{a^2}{2} rac{d^2f}{dx^2}(x,y,t) \
&+f(x,y,t)-a rac{df}{dy}(x,y,t)+ rac{a^{2}}{2} rac{d^{2}f}{dy^{2}}(x,y,t) \
&+f(x,y,t)-a rac{df}{dy}(x,y,t)+ rac{a^2}{2} rac{d^2f}{dy^2}(x,y,t) igg] \
&=(1-r)f(x,y,t)+ rac{r}{4}\left[4f(x,y,t)+2\left( rac{a^2}{2} rac{d^2f}{dx^2}(x,y,t)+ rac{a^2}{2} rac{d^2f}{dy^2}(x,y,t) ight) ight] \
&=f(x,y,t)+ rac{ra^{2}}{4} abla^{2}f(x,y,t),
\end{aligned}$$

where $ abla^2$ is Laplacian. The conclusion above can be simplified as

$$f(x,y,t)+\delta t rac{df}{dt}(x,y,t) =f(x,y,t)+ rac{ra^{2}}4 abla^{2}f(x,y,t) $$

So we get an important equation in physics: the Diffusion Equation, where f will labeled appropriately as T the temperature.

$$
rac{df}{dt}(x,y,t) = rac{ra^2}{4\delta t} abla^2f(x,y,t)
$$

[P22æœ‰ä¸€äº›Jacobiå’ŒGauss-Seidelçš„è¿­ä»£çš„ä»£ç è®°å¾—è¡¥ç®—æ³•æœ¬èº«]

Curve fitting & Error analysis

This chapter mainly talks about Lagrangian interpolating polynomial

WikipediaWiki_zh-CN

THEOREM:

For given n+1 points $(x_i,y_i),i\in [0,n]$, there is only one Lagrangian polynomial L(x) that:

  1. L(x) has the degree <=k
  2. L(x) goes through every node, which means, $ orall i\in [0,n], L(x_i)=y_i$.

L(x) is repersented as

$$L(x)=\sum_{j=0}^ky_j\ell_j(x)$$

where $l_j(x)$ equals
$$ egin{aligned}
\ell_{j}(x)& = rac{(x-x_0)}{(x_j-x_0)}\cdots rac{(x-x_{j-1})}{(x_j-x_{j-1})} rac{(x-x_{j+1})}{(x_j-x_{j+1})}\cdots rac{(x-x_k)}{(x_j-x_k)} \
&=\prod_{\substack{0\leq m\leq k\m eq j}} rac{x-x_m}{x_j-x_m}.
\end{aligned}$$

and the generation of $L(x)$ can be represented as a Polynomial Interpolation algorithm:

Letâ€™s consider as follows:

  1. $L_i(x)$ should goes through $(x_i,y_i)$ and $(x_j,0)$ where $j eq i$
  2. Adding all $l_i(x)$ together will get a curve that goes thourgh all these points.

FFT as recursion for divide and conquer

From continuous to discrete

Suppose we sample a periodic signal (with period T) at N times $y_n=f(t_k n )$ for $n=0â€¦N-1$ at equal time intervalt$t_n=n\Delta t$. The Fouriese serise for a desicrete sample of a â€œtimeâ€ sequence with N terns can be expanded like this:

$$y_n=a_0+\sum_{k=1}^{N_0}[a_k\cos(2\pi kn/N)+b_k\sin(2\pi kn/N)]$$

where $2N_i+1\geq N$. Frequency $\omega_k=2\pi k /N$.

Using Euler Equations
$$\cos( heta)+i\sin( heta)\equiv e^{i heta}$$

we change the equation above into

$$y_n=\sum_{k=0}^{N-1}c_ke^{2\pi ikn/N}$$

itâ€™s a linear equation, and solving $c_k$ by $y_k$ and Gaussian elimimation is a $O(N^3)$ approach.

but thereâ€™s a better trick, notice

$$\sum_ne^{2\pi ikn/N}e^{-2\pi ikâ€™n/N}=\delta_{kkâ€™}$$

we have

$$c_k= rac{1}{N}\sum_{k=0}^{N-1}y_ke^{-i2\pi nk/N}$$

Letâ€™s define $\omega_N^n\equiv e^{i2\pi n/N}$ as the â€œNth roots of unitâ€. You can regard it as a batch of vectors on a unit circle, dividing the circle into N parts evenly. Or you can regard them as somehow a batch of â€œbaseâ€ of vector for a linear space (though not so correct according to the definition).

FFT details

$$y_k\equiv\mathcal{FT}N[c_n]=\sum{n=0}^{N-1}e^{i2\pi nk/N}a_n=\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}(\omega_N^n)^ka_n$$

Use a binary representation of : $n=\sum 2^pn_p, n_p=0,1$
$$\omega_{N}^{n}=\omega_{N}^{n_{0}}\omega_{N/2}^{n_{1}}\omega_{N/4}^{n_{2}}â€¦\omega_{2}^{n_{p}}$$
$$\sum_{n}\omega_{N}^{nk}=\sum_{n_{0}=0,1}\omega_{N/2}^{n_{1}k}\sum_{n_{1}=0,1}\omega_{N}^{n_{0}k}â€¦\sum_{n_{p}=0,1}\omega_{2}^{n_{p}k}$$

Split the polynomial into even and odd parts, Then, we have 2 N/2 FTs:

  • if we do low bit first,
    $$y_k=\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}e^{i2\pi nk/(N/2)}a_{2n}+\omega_N^k\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}e^{i2\pi nk/(N/2)}a_{2n+1}$$
    lower k:
    $$y_k=\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}e^{i2\pi n/(N/2)}[a_{2n}+\omega_N^ka_{2n+1}]$$
    higher k:
    $$y_{k+N/2}=\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}e^{i2\pi n/(N/2)}[a_{2n}-\omega_N^ka_{2n+1}$$

  • if we do high bit first,
    $$y_k=\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}e^{i2\pi nk/N}a_n+e^{i\pi k}\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}e^{i2\pi nk/N}a_{n+N/2}]$$

even k:
$$y_{2 ilde{k}}=\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}e^{i2\pi n ilde{k}/(N/2)}[a_n+a_{n+N/2}]$$
odd k:
$$y_{2 ilde{k}+1}=\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}e^{i2\pi n ilde{k}/(N/2)}\omega_N^n[a_n-a_{n+N/2}]$$

This pattern as a data flow is called the butterfly network.

In summary,
$$ egin{aligned}
y_{k}&=\mathcal{FT}{N/2}[a{2n}+\omega_{N}^{k}a_{2n+1}] \
y_{k+N/2}& =\mathcal{FT}{N/2}[a{2n}-\omega_{N}^{k}a_{2n+1}] \
y_{2k}&=\mathcal{FT}{N/2}[a{n}+a_{n+N/2}] \
y_{2k+1}&=\mathcal{FT}{N/2}\omega{N}^{n}[a_{n}-a_{n+N/2}]
\end{aligned}$$

Multigrid Recursion to speed up Matrix Solvers

entry.content:
ä»Šå¹´ï¼ˆ2024å¹´ï¼‰çš„æ˜æ—¥æ–¹èˆŸå›½æœæ„šäººèŠ‚æ´»åŠ¨æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªèµ›åšæ–—è›è›æ´»åŠ¨ã€‚æ´»åŠ¨çš„ç©æ³•æ˜¯è¿™æ ·çš„ï¼š

  1. ç”¨ä¸€å¥—æƒé‡æµç¨‹ï¼Œä»26ä¸ªå…µç§ä¸­ä¸é‡å¤åœ°é€‰å‡ºä¸€äº›ç§ç±»ï¼Œæ•°é‡å„å¼‚çš„æ€ª
  2. ç”Ÿæˆä¸€ä¸ªåœºåœ°åœ°å›¾
  3. æŠŠæ€ªæŒ‰ç§ç±»å¤§è‡´å‡åˆ†åˆ°ä¸¤ä¾§ï¼Œç„¶åè®©ä»–ä»¬å¤§è‡´éšæœºåœ°ä»ä¸¤ä¾§çš„é—¨åˆ·å‡ºã€‚
  4. ä¸¤ä¾§æ€ªç‰©å¤§è‡´åˆ·å‡ºä¸€åŠåˆ°å…¨éƒ¨æ—¶æš‚åœæ¸¸æˆï¼Œç©å®¶é€‰è¾¹æŠ¼æ³¨ã€‚

å›¾ 1ï¼Œå†…åå°„ k=1 æ—¶çš„ç¤ºæ„å›¾ã€‚k=0ï¼Œå³å…‰çº¿é¦–æ¬¡æ¥è§¦æ°´æ»´å†…è¡¨é¢æ—¶çš„å‡ºå°„å…‰çº¿æœªç”»å‡ºã€‚

å‡è®¾æ°´æ»´ä¸ºåŠå¾„ä¸º R çš„å‡åŒ€çƒä½“ï¼Œç©ºæ°”æŠ˜å°„ç‡ $n_{air}$ï¼Œæ°´æŠ˜å°„ç‡ $n_{water}$ ï¼ŒäºŒè€…éƒ½ä¼šéšå°„å…¥çš„å…‰çš„æ³¢é•¿è€Œå˜åŒ–ï¼Œå³ $n_{air}(\lambda)$ï¼Œ$n_{water}(\lambda)$ã€‚å¤ªé˜³å…‰å¯ä»¥è¿‘ä¼¼ä¸ºå¹³è¡Œå°„å…¥çš„åœ†åæŒ¯å…‰ã€‚

ä»¥çƒå¿ƒä¸ºåŸç‚¹å»ºç«‹ç›´è§’åæ ‡ç³»ï¼Œå¹¶å‡è®¾å…‰æ²¿ç€ $-x$ æ–¹å‘å…¥å°„ï¼Œè¿™æ ·åªéœ€è¦è€ƒè™‘ $x > 0$ éƒ¨åˆ†çš„å…‰ç…§ã€‚åˆç”±äºå¯¹ç§°æ€§ï¼Œåªé¡»è€ƒè™‘ y>=0 éƒ¨åˆ†çš„å³å¯ï¼Œy<0 éƒ¨åˆ†åšé•œåƒå³å¯å¾—åˆ°ã€‚

å‡è®¾å…‰çº¿åœ¨ $(R\cos \theta, R\sin\theta)$ ä½ç½®å…¥å°„ï¼Œè®°å…‰çº¿å…¥å°„çƒçš„ä½ç½®ä¸º $A_0$ï¼Œä¹‹åçƒå†…å…‰çº¿æ¯å†…åå°„ä¸€æ¬¡çš„ä½ç½®ä¸º $A_k(k>=1)$ï¼Œå¦‚ä¸‹å›¾ã€‚

æˆ‘æ˜¯å›¾

å‡è®¾ $A_0$ å¤„çš„å…¥å°„è§’ä¸º $i=\theta$ï¼ŒæŠ˜å°„è§’ä¸º $r$ï¼Œåˆ™å®¹æ˜“å¾—åˆ°

$$

è€ƒè™‘è²æ¶…å°”æ–¹ç¨‹ï¼ˆFresnell Equationï¼‰

å¯¹äºå‘ç”Ÿåœ¨ $n_1$ï¼Œ$n_2$ ä¸¤ä¸ªç•Œé¢ä¸Šçš„æŠ˜åå°„ï¼Œå‡è®¾å…‰çº¿ä»ä»‹è´¨ $n_1$ å°„å…¥ $n_2$ï¼Œå…¥å°„è§’ $\theta_i$ï¼ŒæŠ˜å°„è§’ $\theta_r$ï¼Œåå°„è§’ $\theta_t$ï¼Œå…¥å°„å…‰åŠŸç‡ä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªå•ä½ï¼Œå®¹æ˜“å¾—åˆ°

  1. åå°„å…‰ s åæŒ¯éƒ¨åˆ†åŠŸç‡ $$R_s=\left[\frac{\sin(\theta_t-\theta_i)}{\sin(\theta_t+\theta_i)}\right]^2\tag{3}$$

  2. åå°„å…‰ p åæŒ¯éƒ¨åˆ†åŠŸç‡ $$R_p=\left[\frac{\tan(\theta_r-\theta_i)}{\tan(\theta_r+\theta_i)}\right]^2\tag{4}$$

  3. å¯¹äºåœ†åæŒ¯å…‰ï¼ˆå¤ªé˜³å…‰, å³æœ¬æ–‡æƒ…å†µï¼‰ï¼Œæ€»åŠŸç‡ $$R=(R_s+R_p)/2\tag{5}$$

  4. ä¸ç®¡ä»€ä¹ˆæ—¶å€™ï¼Œéƒ½æœ‰æŠ˜å°„å…‰åŠŸç‡ $$T=1-R\tag{6}$$

æ–¹ä¾¿èµ·è§, æˆ‘ä»¬è®°ç©ºæ°”åˆ°æ°´çš„åå°„ç‡ã€æŠ˜å°„ç‡ä¸º $R_1,T_1$ï¼Œåä¹‹ä¸º $R_2,T_2$ã€‚å…‰çº¿ä»ç©ºæ°”å…¥å°„æ°´æ»´ï¼Œåœ¨æ°´æ»´å†…éƒ¨ç»å†äº† $k\geq 1$ æ¬¡åå°„åå°„å‡ºï¼Œå®¹æ˜“çŸ¥é“ï¼Œç¬¬ k çº§å°„å‡ºæ°´æ»´çš„å…‰çº¿åŠŸç‡ $dP_{out,k}$ å’Œæœ€åˆå…¥å°„å…‰åŠŸç‡ $dP_{i,0}$ çš„æ¯”å€¼

æ°´çš„æŠ˜å°„ç‡æ˜¯æ¸©åº¦å’Œå…‰çš„æ³¢é•¿çš„å‡½æ•°ã€‚å‚è€ƒrefradtiveindex.infoçš„æ°´å’Œç©ºæ°”åœ¨ç‰¹å®šæ¸©åº¦ä¸‹çš„æŠ˜å°„ç‡æ’å€¼è¡¨ï¼Œç®€å•è®°ä¸º

è”ç«‹ $(1)$~$(9)$ å¼ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å†™ä¸€ä¸ªç¨‹åºçœ‹çœ‹åœ†æŸ±ä½“å¯¹å…‰çš„è‰²æ•£æ•ˆæœã€‚è¯¦ç»†ç»“æœè§ä»“åº“çš„cylinder.pyå°±è¡Œã€‚æ•°å€¼ç»˜å›¾å’Œåˆ†æè§1.3.
